revised_title: Heterogeneous Glycine Receptor Localization in Retinal Neurons
tldr: The authors examined the ultrastructural localization of glycine receptors in the turtle retina using a monoclonal antibody. They found that only 56% of synapses made by glycine-utilizing amacrine cells showed glycine receptor immunoreactivity. This indicates that only a portion of the postsynaptic sites contacted by these neurons can respond to glycine, suggesting that a neuron containing multiple neuroactive substances can selectively affect postsynaptic elements by means of heterogeneous receptor localization.
